rangees.data: Distal: tibial tuberosity via the patellar tendon
Superior pole of patella to upper part of suprapatellar recess

content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: Supine position, with the knee and lower third of the thigh exposed

A knee flexion of 20-30° (using a pillow under the popliteal fossa) allows for slight tension in the extensor mechanism, thus reducing problems related to anisotropy of the anterior tendons (caused by their concave profile when the knee is in full extension)[1][4]

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Ask the subject to perform an isometric contraction to locate and palpate the three superficial heads of the quadriceps

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: Examination of the quadriceps tendon (and its constituent bundles)
Check for effusion within the suprapatellar synovial recess
positionnement: In longitudinal view (parallel to the long axis of the thigh), place the distal end of the probe on the patella
If needed, adjust the rotation and tilt angle to minimize anisotropy that could affect the quadriceps tendon

texte: The femur appears as a long hyperechoic line at the lower portion of the image.
The patella (superior dome) is located on the right of the image and can be described as a relatively small hyperechoic area, sloping from right to left and top to bottom
The quadriceps tendon is a thick hyperechoic area crossing the image throughout its width (left to right). Note the clearly visible striated echotexture

The superficial, middle, and deep fascicles (components of the quadriceps tendon) are quite clearly visible in this image. The likely collagenous tissue (hyperechoic) separating each fascicle (less hyperechoic) can be seen
The prefemoral fat cushion is poorly defined in this image, but we can still identify the anatomical site it normally occupies (annotated dotted oval shape).
The suprapatellar fat cushion, like the PFFC, is difficult to identify, but we can also recognize its location here.

vues.title: Transverse View
objectifs: Examination of the quadriceps tendon (and its constituent bundles)
positionnement: Rotate the probe 90° from the longitudinal view

texte: The vastus medialis appears as a hypoechoic area on the left side of the image.

The quadriceps tendon, when observed in the 'normal' image (without anisotropy), appears as a large fusiform hyperechoic area. A fibrillar structure can also be observed (alternating hyper- and hypoechoic fascicles within the tendon).
In the image with anisotropy (image 7/8), the tendon appears as a hypoechoic area, while the surrounding structures (e.g., fascias, adipose tissue) maintain their more hyperechoic appearance.

text: The quadriceps tendon (QT) (not to be confused with the patellar tendon) is one of the three structures composing the knee extensor apparatus (the other two structures being the patellar tendon and the patella).
